turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: I don't care what his family's like or if he doesn't have any brothers, but he doesn't have to lie to me.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: I really don't know what to say. Look, I lie to women all the time. That's just my way.  Last week Morgan brought these girls down from Roslindale. I told them I was a cosmonaut. They believed me. But Will's not usually like that--

turns.speaker: SKYLAR
turns.text: Is that true?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Yeah, it is.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: --That isn't funny--

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: --and he's like "shit! Motherfucker!" And he looks in his rearview and sees this cat-- I'm sorry--

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Jesus.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: And all the time he's apologizin' to the cat, goin' "I'm sorry." BANG, "I'm sorry." BANG!

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: WILL!

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: And so they go around to the front of his truck...and there's another cat on the grille.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Yah, that is a nice ass.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: You could put a pool in that backyard.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Fuck this, let's get something to eat...

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: What Morgan, you're not gonna go talk to her?

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Fuck her.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Morgan, I'm not goin' to "Kelly's Roast Beef" just cause you like the take-out girl. It's fifteen minutes out of our way. MORGAN What else we gonna do we can't spare fifteen minutes?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: All right Morgan, fine. I'll tell you why we're not going to "Kelly's." It's because the take-out bitch is a fuckin' idiot. I'm sorry you like her but she's dumb as a post and she has never got our order right, never once.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: She's not stupid.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Would you shut the fuck up! I know what you ordered, I was there!

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: So why don't you give me my sandwhich?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: What do you mean "your sandwhich?" I bought it.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Yah, all right...

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: How much money you got?

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: I told you, I just got change.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Well give me your fuckin' change and we'll put your fuckin' sandwhich on lay-away.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Why you gotta be an asshole Chuckie?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: I think you should establish a good line of credit.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Did she get my Double Burger?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: NO SHE DIDN'T GET YOUR DOUBLE BURGER!! IT'S ALL FUCKIN' FLYIN' FISH FILET!!

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Come on, Will...

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: No, why didn't you fight him at the park if you wanted to? I'm not goin' now, I'm eatin' my snack. WILL  So don't go.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Morgan, Let's go.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: I'm serious Chuckie, I ain't goin'.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: You got fired from pushing a broom, you little bitch.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Yah, that was different. Management was restructurin'--

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: My uncle can probably get you on my demo team.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: What the fuck? I just asked you for a job yesterday!

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: I told you "no" yesterday!

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Some other guy?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Yeah, he was probably drunker than my Uncle, who fuckin' knows? So the cop goes "Stay here" And he goes runnin' down the highway to deal with the other crash. So, my Uncle Marty's standin' on the side of the road for a little while, and he's so fuckin' lit, that he forgets what he's waitin' for. So he goes, "Fuck it." He gets in his car and drives home.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Holy shit.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: So in the morning, there's a knock on the door it's the Statie. So my Uncle's like, "Is there a problem?" And the Statie's like "I pulled you over and you took off." And my Uncle's like "I never seen you before in my life, I been home all night with my kids." And Statie's like "Let me get in your garage!" So he's like "All right, fine." He takes around the garage and opens the door --and the Statie's cruiser is in my Uncle's garage.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Did your Uncle get arrested?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: The fuckin' Trooper was so embarrassed he didn't do anything. The fuckin' guy had been drivin' around in my Uncle's car all night lookin' for the house.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: It's a good thing no one's Irish here.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: I'm Irish.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Chuck, let's go.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: You're walkin' bitch, Will's takin' the car.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: What's up guys?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Why don't you beat off at your house?

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: I don't have a VCR at my house.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Oh my God, I got the most fucked up thing I been meanin' to tell you.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Save it for your mother, funny guy. We heard it before.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Oh, Morgan.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: What'd you say about me?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Shut the fuck up.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Hey, asshole. Happy Birthday.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: You thought we forgot, didn't you? I know I'm gettin' my licks in.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Me and Bill scraped together the parts, worked on it. Morgan was out panhandlin' every day.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Fuck you, I did the body work. Whose fuckin' router you think sanded out all that bondo?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Guy's been up my ass for two years about a fuckin' job. I had to let him help with the car.

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: I'm not sure--

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: --These circumstances are mitigated. Right now. They're mitigated.

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: Will, our offer starts you at eighty- four thousand a year, plus benefits.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Retainer...

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: You want us to give you cash right now?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Allegedly, what I am saying is your situation will be concurrently improved if I had two hundred sheets in my pocket right now.

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: I don't think I...Larry?

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: I have about seventy-three...

turns.speaker: EXECUTIVE
turns.text: Will you take a check?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Come now...what do you think I am, a juvinile? You don't got any money on you right now. You think I'm gonna take a check? EXECUTIVE It's fine, John, I can cover the rest.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What class did you say that was?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: History.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: How'd you like that course?

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Good, it was all right.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: History? Just "history?" It must have been a survey course then.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: Hey, come on pal we're in classes all day. That's one thing about Harvard never seizes to amaze me, everybody's talkin' about school all the time.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Hey, I'm the last guy to want to talk about school at the bar. But as long as you're here I want to "seize" the opportunity to ask you a question.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: To tell you the truth, I wasn't there much. The class was rather elementary.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Elementary? Oh, I don't doubt that it was. I remember the class, it was just between recess and lunch.

turns.speaker: CHUCKIE
turns.text: All right, are we gonna have a problem?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: There's no problem. I was just hoping you could give me some insight into the evolution of the market economy in the early colonies. My contention is that prior to the Revolutionary War the economic modalities especially of the southern colonies could most aptly be characterized as agrarian pre- capitalist and...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So why do you think I should work for the National Security Agency?

turns.speaker: DYTRESS
turns.text: Well, you'd be working on the cutting edge. You'd be exposed to the kind of technology you couldn't see anywhere else because we've classified it. Super string theory, Chaos Math, Advanced algorithms--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Codebreaking.

turns.speaker: DYTRESS
turns.text: That's one aspect of what we do.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Come on, that's what you do. You handle more than eighty percent of the intelligence workload. You're seven times the size of the C.I.A.

turns.speaker: DYTRESS
turns.text: That's exactly right, Will. So the question as I see it isn't "why should you work for N.S.A." it's "why shouldn't you?"

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why shouldn't I work for the National Security Agency? That's a tough one.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: Okay, you're in your bed, Will. Now how old are you?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Seven.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: And what do you see?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Somethin's in my room.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's like a small figure, hoverin' over me. Gettin' closer.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: You're in a safe place, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's touching me.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: Where is it touching you?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Down there.  And I'm nervous.

turns.speaker: HYPNOTIST
turns.text: You don't have to be nervous, Will.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Alexander, I know your theory. The boy is updating, he's strategy stealing...

turns.speaker: PEKEC
turns.text: With a Ramses graph on the binary tree--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --But what he's doing, he's attaching an edge to the adjacent vertex. He can always failsafe to either side--

turns.speaker: PEKEC
turns.text: Maker can. This is not new, Gerry!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: No, there's a limit.

turns.speaker: PEKEC
turns.text: The limit is not found!  The limit is not found.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --Maker builds "K" to the "N." N is three to the K times--

turns.speaker: PEKEC
turns.text: --But--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Excuse me. Is this the buildings and grounds office?

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Yeah, can I help you?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I'm trying to find the name of a student who works here.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: No students work for me.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Could you just check, because the young man who works in my building--

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Which one's your building?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Building two.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Well, if something was stolen, I should know about it.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: No, no. Nothing like that. I just need his name. TERRY I can't give you his name unless you have a complaint.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Please, I'm a professor here and it's very important.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Well, he didn't show up for work today...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What're you doing?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What's your name?  Don't you walk away from me. This is people's work, you can't graffiti here.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Hey fuck you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Well... I'll be speaking to your supervisor.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Hello. Gerald Lambeau, M.I.T.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Fuck do you want?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I've spoken with the judge and he's agreed to release you under my supervision.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Yes. Under two conditions.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What're those?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That you meet with me twice a week--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: If I agree to this, I walk right now?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'll do the work. I'm not going to meet with a therapist.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Now, it won't be as bad as it sounds, Will.  I've already spoken to one therapist, his name is Henry Lipkin and he's a friend of mine. He's also published four books and is widely considered to be one of the brightest men in his field.  I'm sure it'll be better than spending the next six months in jail.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: This rectangle is subdivided into rectangles. One edge of an inner rectangle is an integer. Can you prove that one edge of the larger rectangle is an integer?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Okay. How?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's an integer proof.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That would be a monumental waste of time, wouldn't it, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I happen to know so.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Half-red, half-black--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --that?--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --Half-red, half-black--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --That edge!

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: An integer.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Shall we start the, uh...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, when do I get my hypnosis? You guys been talkin' for twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Oh, for God's sake, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Oh, come on! You're not pinnin' this one on me. He left, I wanted to talk to him for another twenty minutes. I was havin' fun.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I told you to cooperate with these people.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: C'mon, that guy was a fuckin' piece of work.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Get out, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Okay...don't forget to get another therapist for next week.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That's enough.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Will, this is Sean Maguire. Sean, Will Hunting.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: This is correct. I see you used Mclullen here--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I don't know what it's called.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --This can't be right.  This is going to be very embarrassing. Have you ever considered--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm pretty sure it's right.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Can I ask you a favor, can we do this at Sean's from now on? 'Cause I leave work to come here and the fuckin' commute is killin' me--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That's fine, but did you ever think--

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's right.  Take it home with you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Will, what happened at the Tri-tech meeting?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I couldn't go 'cause I had a date. So I sent my cheif negotiator.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Will, on your own time, you can do what you like. When I set up a meeting, with my associates, and you don't show up it reflects poorly on me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Then don't set up any more meetings.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I'll cancel every meeting right now. I'll give you a job myself. I just wanted you to see what was out there.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --Maybe I don't want to spend my life sittin' around and explaining shit to people.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: The least you can do is show me a little appreciation.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: --You know how fuckin' easy this is to me? This is a joke!  And I'm sorry you can't do this. I really am. 'Cause if you could I wouldn't be forced to watch you fumble around and fuck it up.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sure, then you'd have more time to sit around and get drunk. Think of how many fights you could have been in by now.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: So am I.  Yes. That's right, Will. Most days I wish I never met you. Because then I could sleep at night. I wouldn't have to walk around with the knowledge that someone like you was out there. And I wouldn't have to watch you throw it all away.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What are you smiling at?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's a Carlton Fisk baseball card.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I can come back.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: No, that's fine, Will. I was just leaving.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Hey, how you doin'?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You know, you're no longer required to come here.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I was just sayin' goodbye to Sean.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sam called me. From Tri-tech. He says you start working for them next week.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I just want you to know...It's been a pleasure.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Bullshit.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: This job... Do it if it's what you really want.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I appreciate that.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Listen, I'll be nearby so, if you need some help, or you get stuck again, don't be afraid to give me a call.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Thank you, Will. I'll do that.

turns.speaker: STUDENT
turns.text: Excuse me, Professor Lambeau?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STUDENT
turns.text: I'm in your applied theories class. We're all down at the Math and Science building.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: It's Saturday.

turns.speaker: STUDENT
turns.text: I know. We just couldn't wait 'till Monday to find out.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Find out what?

turns.speaker: STUDENT
turns.text: Who proved the theorem.

turns.speaker: TIMMY
turns.text: Good to meet you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Pleasure to meet you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Excuse me, Timmy. Could you help us? We're trying to settle a bet.

turns.speaker: TIMMY
turns.text: Uh-oh.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Have you heard of Jonas Salk?

turns.speaker: TIMMY
turns.text: Yeah, cured polio.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You've heard of Albert Einstein?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: How about Gerald Lambeau? Ever heard of him?

turns.speaker: TIMMY
turns.text: No. LAMBEAU Okay thank you, Timmy.

turns.speaker: TIMMY
turns.text: So who won the bet?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sean.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Well, it seems we're in the presence of greatness. Professor Gerald Lambeau is a Field's Medal winner. Combunatorial Mathematics. 1986.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: The Field's Medal is the Nobel Prize for math.  But it's only given out every four years.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Good to see you.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Good to see you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Is there someplace we can talk?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I didn't see you at the reunion.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I've been busy.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You were missed.  How long has it been since we've seen each other?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Since Nancy died.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I'm sorry, that damn conference--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I got your card.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I've been busy, Gerry. I got a full schedule.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: This kid's special, Sean. I've never seen anything like him.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Not much free time, Gerry. LAMBEAU Have you ever heard of a man named Ramanujan?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: He was alive over a hundred years ago. He was Indian. Dots, not feathers...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: And he mailed it to Hardy--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --That's right, Sean. He mailed it to a professor at Cambridge who immediately recognized the brilliance in his work and brought Ramanujan to England.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Where he contracted pneumonia and died at a young age--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: They worked together for the remainder of their lives, producing some of the most exciting math theory ever done. Ramanujan's genius was unparalleled, Sean. This boy is like that. But he's very defensive and I need someone who can get through to him.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Why me?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I need someone with your kind of background.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: My kind of background?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You're from the same neighborhood. South Boston.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: He's from Southie? How many people did you try before you came to me?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Five.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Not Rick? You didn't send him to Rick?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Just meet with the boy once a week.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Can we do it at my office?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That would be fine.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I got it.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: It's on the college.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Any vulnerability he senses, he'll exploit.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I'll be okay.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: It's a poker game with this young man. Don't let him see what you've got.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Would you excuse us?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Tom.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You too, Gerry.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What do you mean "he didn't talk?" You sat there for an hour?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: No, he just sat there and counted the seconds until the session was over. It was pretty impressive, actually.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Why would he do that?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: To show me he doesn't have to talk to me if he doesn't want to.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Oh, what is this? Some kind of staring contest between two kids from the "old neighborhood?"

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I won't talk first.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Gerry! Any trouble finding the place?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Timmy this is Gerry, an old friend of mine. We went to college together.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You're here quite a bit, then.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I live right around the corner.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You moved?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I been here a couple years.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Seems like it's going well.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Well, have you talked to him at all about his future?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: We haven't really gotten into it. LAMBEAU Maybe you should. My phone's been ringing off the hook with job offers.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Jobs doing what?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Cutting edge mathematics. Think tanks. The kind of place where a mind like Will's is given free reign.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: That's great, Gerry, that there's interest-- But I'm not sure he's ready for that.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sean, I really don't think you understand--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: What don't I understand?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: He married his cousin.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Einstein. Had two marriages, both train-wrecks. The guy never saw his kids, one of whom, I think, ended up in an asylum--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You see, Sean? That's exactly not the point. No one remembers that. They--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Well, you're the only one.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Just...take it easy, Gerry.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Look, I don't know what else I can say. I'm not sitting at home every night, twisting my mustache and hatching a plan to ruin the boy's life. But it's important to start early. I was doing advanced mathematics at eighteen and it still took me twenty-three years to do something worthy of a Field's medal.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Maybe he doesn't care about that.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sean, this is important. And it's above personal rivalry--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Now wait a minute, Gerry--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --No, no you hear me out, Sean. This young man is a true prodigy--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --Personal rivalry? I'm not getting back at you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Look, you took one road and I took another. That's fine.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Is it Gerry? 'Cause I don't think it's fine with you. Give him time to figure out what he wants.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That's a wonderful theory, Sean. It worked wonders for you.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: This is a disaster! I brought you in here to help me with this boy, not to run him out--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Now wait a minute--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --And confuse him--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --Gerry--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --And here I am for the second week in a row with my professional reputation at stake--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Hold on!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --Ready to falsify documents because you've given him license to walk away from this.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I know what I'm doing and I know why I'm here!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Look Sean, I don't care if you have a rapport with the boy-- I don't care if you have a few laughs-- even at my expense! But don't you dare undermine what I'm trying to do here.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: "Undermine?"

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: He has a gift and with that gift comes responsibility. And you don't understand that he's at a fragile point--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: He is at a fragile point. He's got problems--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What problems does he have, Sean, that he is better off as a janitor or in jail or hanging around with--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Why do you think he does that, Gerry?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: He can handle the work, he can handle the pressure and he's obviously handled you.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Why is he hiding? Why is he a janitor? Why doesn't he trust anybody? Because the first thing that happened to him was that he was abandoned by the people who were supposed to love him the most!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Oh, come on, Sean--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --And why does he hang out with his friends? Because any one of those kids would come in here and take a bat to your head if he asked them to. It's called loyalty!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Oh, that's nice--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --And who do you think he's handling? He pushes people away before they have a chance to leave him. And for 20 years he's been alone because of that. And if you try to push him into this, it's going to be the same thing all over again. And I'm not going to let that happen to him!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Now don't do that. Don't you do that! Don't infect him with the idea that it's okay to quit. That it's okay to be a failure, because it's not okay! If you're angry at me for being successful, for being what you could have been--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --I'm not angry at you--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --Yes you are, Sean. You resent me. And I'm not going to apologize for any success that I've had.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --I don't have any anger at you--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Yes you do. You're angry at me for doing what you could have done. Ask yourself if you want Will to feel that way for the rest of his life, to feel like a failure.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: That's it. That's why I don't come to the goddamn reunions! Becaue I can't stand the look in your eye when you see me! You think I'm a failure! I know who I am. I'm proud of who I am. And all of you, you think I'm some kind of pity case! You with your sycophant students following you around. And you Goddamn Medal!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: --Is that what this is about, Sean? The Field's Medal? Do you want me to go home and get it for you? Then will you let the boy--

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: --I don't want your trophy and I don't give a shit about it! 'Cause I knew you when!! You and Jack and Tom Sanders. I knew you when you were homesick and pimply-faced and didn't know what side of the bed to piss on!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: That's right! You were smarter than us then and you're smarter than us now! So don't blame me for how your life turned out. It's not my fault.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I don't blame you! It's not about that! It's about the boy! 'Cause he's a good kid! And I won't see this happen to him-- I won't see you make him feel like a failure too!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: He won't be a failure!

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: If you push him into something, if you ride him--

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: You're wrong, Sean. I'm where I am today because I was pushed. And because I learned to push myself!

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: He's not you!

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Hello, Sean.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sean...

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: So I hear you're taking some time.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Yeah. Summer vacation. Thought I'd travel some. Maybe write a little bit.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Where're you going?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I don't know. India maybe.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Why there?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Never been.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Do you know when you'll be back?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I got this mailer the other day. Class of Sixty-five is having this event in six months.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: I got one of those too.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You should come. I'll buy you a drink.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: How about one now?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: Sounds good.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: Sean, do you have any idea what the odds are against winning the lottery?

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: I don't know... Gotta be at least four to one.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: About thirty million to one.

turns.speaker: SEAN
turns.text: You're pretty quick with those numbers. How about the odds of me buying the first round?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: About thirty million to one.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I called Mel Weintraub this morning, to check for availability.

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: What's the point?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: There is somebody...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: He was my roommate in college.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What should I do?

turns.speaker: LAMBEAU
turns.text: The boy was here. He came in, sat down and we worked together.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: It's walkin' pretty slow at this point.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: You guys are fuckin' sick.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I could go for a Whopper.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Let's hit "Kelly's."

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Well, she out did herself today...

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: I don't got a crush on her.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: What happened?  You got fired, huh?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, Morgan. I got fired.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: How fuckin' retarded do you have to be to get shit-canned from that job? How hard is it to push a fuckin' broom?

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: There goes that fuckin' Barney right now, with his fuckin' "skiin' trip." We should'a kicked that dude's ass.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Hold up.

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Will, I can't believe you brought Skylar here when we're all wrecked. What's she gonna think about us?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, Morgan. It's a real rarity that we'd be out drinkin'.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So, you finally got a job Morgan?

turns.speaker: MORGAN
turns.text: Had one, now I'm fucked again.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So what do you got, a fuckin' Hyundai engine under there? Can I make it back to my house?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: That's why I love stock-car racin'. That Dale Ernhart's real good.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Now you know Will, and I know, what you need to be doing. You have a gift.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I could work the pit maybe, but I could never drive like Dale Ernhart--

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: --you have a quality-- something you were born with, that you have no control over- and you are, in a sense, hiding that by becoming a janitor. And I'm not saying that's wrong. I'm friends with the janitor that works in my building. He's been to my house for dinner. As a matter of fact I did some free consultation for "Mike" -- that's not his real name. That's in my book.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Yeah, I read your book. "Mike" had the same problems as "Chad" the stockbroker.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Yes. The pressures you feel, and again, I am neither labeling nor judging them, are keeping you from fulfilling your potential -- you're in a rut. So stop the Tom Foolery -- the Shenanigan's, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're right. I know.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Will, your not getting off that easy.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No, but, I mean you know...I do other things. That no one knows about.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Like what, Will?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I go places, I interact.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: What places?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Certain, clubs.  Like, Paradise. It's not bad.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: I might understand that.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Do you find it hard to hide the fact that you're gay?

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: C'mon, I read your book. I talked to you. It's just something I know to be true.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: That's very presumptuous.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Buddy, two seconds ago you were ready to give me a jump.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry to disappoint you, but I'm married and I have two children.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm sure you do. You probably got a real nice house, nice car -- your book's a best seller.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: You're getting defensive, Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Look, man. I don't care if you're putting from the rough. There are solid arguments that some of the greatest people in history were gay; Alexander the Great, Caeser, Shakespeare, Oscar Wilde, Napoleon, Gertrude Stein, not to mention Danny Terrio, not many straight men can dance like that.

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Who is "Danny Terrio?"

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: If you wanna hit "Ramrod," take your shot. Take some pride in it. You go to church? So fuckin' what, God loves you. I mean, Christ. A guy as well known as you? By the time you put your disguise on and skulk out of the house Sunday nights you probably look like "Inspector Cluseau."

turns.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
turns.text: Well, I can see this is pointless...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're getting defensive...Henry. And hey, cheif--tell the wife, at least. Christ, set her free.
